1.brief: gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
properly, to be open, wide or free, i.e. (by implication) to be safe; causatively, to free or succor
force (literally or figuratively); by implication, valor, victory
a straight course, i.e. sail direct

2.brief: gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
intercession, supplication; by implication, a hymn
to broaden out the ear (with the hand), i.e. (by implication) to listen
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to

3.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
to turn aside (especially for lodging); hence to be aforeigner, strange, profane; specifically (active participle) to commit adultery
to rise (in various applications, literal, figurative, intensive and causative)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
to search out (by any method, specifically in worship or prayer); by implication, to strive after
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to put (used in a great variety of applications, literal, figurative, inferentially, and elliptically)

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
a front, i.e. part opposite; specifically a counterpart, or mate; usually (adverbial, especially with preposition) over against or before

4.brief: gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
to surround, i.e. protect or aid
the Lord (used as a proper name of God only)
to prop (literally or figuratively); reflexively, to lean upon or take hold of (in a favorable or unfavorable sense)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)

5.brief: to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
to be hostile (only active participle an opponent)

6.brief: properly (abstractly) spontaneity, or (adjectively) spontaneous; also (concretely) a spontaneous or (by inference, in plural) abundant gift
to slaughter an animal (usually in sacrifice)
physically, to throw (a stone, an arrow) at or away; especially to revere or worship (with extended hands); intensively, to bemoan (by wringing the hands)
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)

7.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
tightness (i.e. figuratively, trouble); transitively, a female rival:
to snatch away, whether in a good or a bad sense
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)

8.brief: properly (abstractly) spontaneity, or (adjectively) spontaneous; also (concretely) a spontaneous or (by inference, in plural) abundant gift
to slaughter an animal (usually in sacrifice)
physically, to throw (a stone, an arrow) at or away; especially to revere or worship (with extended hands); intensively, to bemoan (by wringing the hands)
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)

9.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
tightness (i.e. figuratively, trouble); transitively, a female rival:
to snatch away, whether in a good or a bad sense
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
